page.title: 18QUORNDEN WOOD
page.content: This area of land was used for grazing until 1853 and then small timber started to be grown on it. The timber was produced by coppicing which means that the trees were cut off at ground level every few years so that small poles would grow. Most of the coppice wood was used by the charcoal burners and the main use of the charcoal was to dry out the local hops in the many oast houses around the hill. Now there is very little demand for beech coppice poles and therefore the coppice have been "singled" leaving one pole to grow into a large tree.
